title: SoCal R Users Group (SoCal RUG): Book club  - Communicating with Data  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Are you looking to improve your data communication skills? Come just us for a book club. It will be headed up by Neal Fultz. The idea is to motivate us to read books and discussing them together. This will help all of us to develop our skills.

The format will be that the leader will prepare a short summary of the material and present it to the group. We will then discuss the material and do some exercises.

The expectations are that you will attend regularly. If you cannot make a commitment to attend, please wait until the next book club starts. It is also expected that participants will take turns being the leader. The leader should prepare a summary of the material that was read and present it to the group.

We will meet each week, Wednesday between 3:30 and 5:00 PM PST for eight weeks.

Book: Title: Communicating with Data: The Art of Writing for Data Science
Dead Tree: https://global.oup.com/academic/product/communicating-with-data-9780198862758

Signing up: When you sign-up you will be placed on the waiting list. We always have a lot of interest but the book club is a significant commitment. The coordinator will confirm your commitment. Please make sure that you get meet-up emails.

title: SoCal R Users Group (SoCal RUG): Interview Take-home Challenges  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Are you looking to land a data science job and want to practice take-home challenges? Did you spend hours and hours on take-home challenges which supposed to be finished in under 3 hours but have no feedback? Come join us for a coding camp. It will be headed up by Xi Chen. The idea is to motivate us to code and sharpen our skills. This will help all of us so you never have to worry about the technical interview again.

The format will be that the organizer will hand out two take-home challenges one week in advance. You can choose either one or both to complete by yourself. Feel free to use Python or R. We will then discuss them together during the session.

The expectations are that you will actually make effort to do the take-home problems each week. If you cannot make a commitment, please wait until the next club starts. It is expected that participants will complete the challenges or do the best they can within 3 hours. Experience suggests that this is a lower limit and it can be much more time.

We will meet each week, Wednesday between 6:30 and 8:00 PM PST for six weeks. The first dataset will go out on July 7th.

Signing up: When you sign-up you will be placed on the waiting list. We always have a lot of interest but the club is a significant commitment. The coordinator will confirm your commitment. Please make sure that you get meet-up emails.

title: The Chicago R User Group (CRUG): Summer of Lightning Talks! üéâ üçª üéâ üç∑, United States, US/Canada
description:
A continuation of our return to live and in person meetings, please join us in rebooting the Chicago R User Group with another evening of lightning talks and an open mic!

**Doors open at 5:00, talks begin at 5:30!**

In the spirit of Open Source we welcome you, Chicagoland R users, to attend and consider contributing a short talk on the novel work you're proud of. As always, slides including simple code that can be displayed in a readable way is encouraged. Register here to present and/or just Bring Your Own Slide Deck for the Open Mic! (https://forms.gle/oE7pXjkUzKyXuvQH9)

Lightning-ish talks of 10-20 minutes, follow by an Open Mic on any R related topic, on a FIFO basis. The following talks are on deck:

Dr. Adan Z. Becerra, Assistant Professor and Associate Program Director for Clinical Research, Dept. of Surgery, Rush University (https://www.linkedin.com/in/adan-z-becerra-phd-82ba34126/). Adan will give us a fun and accessible talk on Bayesian multilevel models and data visualizations with ggplot2.

Justin M Shea, Assistant Professor of Finance and Executive Director of the Clearing Corporation Charitable Fund Finance Honors program at Roosevelt University (https://www.linkedin.com/in/justinmshea/). Extending a talk produced for the Bureau of Labor Statistics in March, Justin will present Time Series Data, Best Practices in R. Working examples will be on real financial data sets of varying sizes and periodicities.

** We are monitoring daily infection counts (currently falling) and will adjust the parameters of this event based on guidance from the City of Chicago and local experts in the field **

As vaccination rates continue to increase, Governor Pritzker issued guidelines for all Illinois Businesses to reopen on June 11th. (https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/news-item.aspx?ReleaseID=23399)
In step with the Governor, Chicago Mayor Lori Lightfoot moved up the city's time table to match the state of Illinois, and also fully reopened on June 11th. (https://www.reuters.com/world/us/chicago-reopen-fully-june-11-mayor-says-2021-06-04/)

Given our commitment to gathering safely, we are incentivizing vaccination of all in attendance by giving you FREE beverage tickets if you can display proof of receiving a COVID-19 vaccine. So bring your vaccine card and enjoy a beverage! üç∑üçª üç∑üçª

But wait...there's more! You may also receive a free plastic sleeve to protect your vaccine card. However, in the spirit of Reduce, Reuse, Recycle ‚ôª (hat tip, Troy Hernandez) you should reuse one of the many lanyards you've acquired from the conference circuit if possible.

If you aren't vaccinated, you still have time as doses are becoming widely available! Please visit the Illinois Department of Health COVID-19 Vaccine FAQ page for more details. (https://www.dph.illinois.gov/covid19/vaccine-faq)

As always, please reach out to us with any questions or concerns. We look forward to seeing you live and in person at the Haymarket Pub & Brewery soon!

title: CaRdiff - the Cardiff R User Group: Tidy Thursday: Summer 2021 Remote Workshop  [Virtual] , United Kingdom, Europe
group: CaRdiff - the Cardiff R User Group
description:
Come join us for this next Tidy Thursday session.

Tidy Tuesdays are weekly R projects on 'tidying' data, associated (but not exclusive!) to the 'tidyverse': ggplot2, dplyr, tidyr and friends.

You can find out more about Tidy Tuesdays here: https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday

We will meet (on Thursday!), find the most recent data set and 'tidy' it up together.

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
This week dataset is Scooby-Doo :)
https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/tree/master/data/2021/2021-07-13
++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

This session will be beginner-friendly, hands-on, and potentially pair programming driven.

Learning outcomes: Data Preparation, Data Munging, Tidy Data, Tidyverse

It would be helpful for attendees to have the following already installed, but if you run into trouble we can help on the day.

* R: https://www.r-project.org/
* R Studio desktop: https://rstudio.com/products/rstudio/
* Tidyverse: https://www.tidyverse.org/

These are all free tools, and install will take roughly 20-40 min depending on hardware and internet speeds.

Our previous work is available here:
https://github.com/CaRdiffR/tidy_thursdays

title: Central Iowa R User Group: R and Python study group, United States, US/Canada
description:
Until we can meet again in person, please join our Slack workspace to stay in touch, ask questions, and share information throughout the week.

https://join.slack.com/t/centraliowarusergroup/shared_invite/zt-dhfa5ude-0tvHascxRkn2pgiqDdQgrw

The Slack workspace is available any time, not just Saturday mornings.

Are you tired of learning and playing with Python and R alone? Would you like to get together with a few friends and learn together? I have been starting to learn R and Python for data science and following the typical route of videos and practice projects. I really want to ramp up my learning and exposure to different ways. Here is my proposal:

- Gather a small group of 2-5 and learn together.
- Meet at a coffee shop, library, or some other space that has Wi-Fi.
- Pick a project, data set or problem, then work to solve it with different tools.
- Keep it fluid and informal.
- Meet on a regular basis, say weekly to start, and adjust as needed.
- Aim to keep the meetings 2-4 hours long, but this can be adjusted to the project or group. People can come and go as needed.
- It does not have to be the same people each time, so you only have to commit to going once to check it out.

Are you interested? Show up at the meeting spot, have some coffee, meet new friends and bring a project or question.

title: Berlin R Users Group: #45 A long-short Bayesian State-Space model with R and RStan  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
Welcome to our 2nd own Berlin RUG online meetup! We'll learn about bayesian modeling for a forecast on our upcoming election. And we will get to see each other again, so we're hoping many will sign up :)

A long-short Bayesian State-Space model for the German Federal Election 2021 with R and RStan

# Description
Marcus Gro√ü and Michelle Golchert will present a Bayesian model for forecasting the German federal election 2021 with R and RStan that gives more insights and more accurate predictions compared to simple poll-averaging methods. The model consists of two parts:
A model for the election outcome (i.e. the vote share for each party based on poll data) and a model to assign a probability to the coalition of the actual government using expert survey data. An in-depth description and motivation is discussed in this talk. The model is fitted with (R)Stan, a Bayesian modeling framework, that can seamlessly be integrated into R.

# Agenda
18:30 Intro
18:35 Talk
19:05 Q&A
19:30 Closing remarks (we can extend it if needed)

# Bios
Marcus Gro√ü and Michelle Golchert are Data Scientists at INWT Statistics.
Marcus holds a Ph.D. in Statistics and has several years experience consulting on and managing projects in the data science field. He is an expert in predictive analytics and Bayesian statistics.
Michelle has a master's degree in psychology and specializes in supporting Data Science projects in the areas of software development, DevOps and CI.

title: Greater Boston useR Group (R Programming Language): shiny.fluent and shiny.react: Build beautiful Shiny apps (June useR Meetup)  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: Greater Boston useR Group (R Programming Language)
description:
shiny.fluent and shiny.react: Build beautiful Shiny apps using Microsoft's Fluent UI
Presentation by Kamil ≈ªy≈Ça

Abstract:
In this talk we will present the functionality and ideas behind a new open-source package Appsilon developed called shiny.fluent. UI plays a huge role in the success of Shiny projects. shiny.fluent enables you to build Shiny apps in a novel way using Microsoft‚Äôs Fluent UI as the UI foundation. It gives your app a beautiful, professional look and a rich set of components while retaining the speed of development that Shiny is famous for.

Fluent UI is based on the Javascript library React, so it‚Äôs a challenging task to make it work with Shiny. We have put the parts responsible for making this possible in a separate package called shiny.react, which enables you to port other React-based components and UI libraries so that they work in Shiny.

During the talk we will demonstrate how to use shiny.fluent to build your own Shiny apps, and explain how we solved the main challenges in integrating React and Shiny

Speaker Bio:
Kamil is a Full Stack Engineer at Appsilon. He graduated with degrees in Computer Science and Mathematics from the University of Warsaw. He is passionate about working across various technologies, leading projects, and developing internal tooling. Privately, he enjoys listening to
jazz and has an interest in psychology and philosophy.

title: Greater Boston useR Group (R Programming Language): Virtual Boston useR July Meetup!  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: Greater Boston useR Group (R Programming Language)
description:
*please note the date change to 7/26 so that we do not overlap with useR! conference

Boston useR July Meetup!
Presentations by Kaija Gahm & Ralph Asher

Agenda:
12-12:05 - welcome & introductions
12:05 - 12:20 - Kaija Gahm: greenT Shiny app
12:20 - 12:40 - Ralph Asher: Introduction to Monte Carlo simulation, using Shiny
12:40 - 1:00 - Q&A

*greenT Shiny app:
greenT is a Shiny app I built to explore grapheme-color synesthesia, a neurological phenomenon where letters/numbers (graphemes) are associated with colors in my mind. Whenever friends found out about my synesthesia, they would want to know what color their names were in my head, and it got to be challenging to explain. When I found myself manually coloring squares in a spreadsheet to demonstrate what I saw in my mind's eye, I decided to build an app instead. The app lets you either set your own colors or see what mine look like. Then you can enter text, and it will display as a series of rectangles according to the colors you've selected. I also added a feature that mimics a Google form to collect survey responses from other people with synesthesia, so they can submit their color data if they want to.

Bio:
My name is Kaija (rhymes with Maya), and I'm an incoming PhD student in the ecology/evolutionary biology department at UCLA, where I'll be studying movement ecology and behavior of vultures using social network analysis. I've been using R for about six years, and for the past year I've been working as a data manager for an ecosystem science nonprofit. I'm on the board of SORTEE, an organization focused on openness and reproducibility in ecology and evolutionary biology. I didn't come from a computer science background, so I'm passionate about talking to people about incorporating R into their work in accessible and friendly ways.

When I'm not at my computer, you can usually find me outdoors (hiking or birdwatching) or spending entire days in the kitchen making up recipes. I tweet and blog, mostly about R.

*Introduction to Monte Carlo simulation, using Shiny
Monte Carlo Simulation is a powerful methodology to model and understand the impact of uncertainty upon real life. In this talk, I will introduce Monte Carlo simulation through a simple example: I'm meeting my neighbor after work for dinner in our neighborhood. Given the uncertain length of our commutes, will we make it in time for our reservation? I'll talk through the scenario, then walk through a simple Shiny app that explores the power of Monte Carlo Simulation to recommend decisions under uncertainty.

Bio:
I am Ralph Asher, and I am the founder of Data Driven Supply Chain LLC, a Minnesota-based consultancy that helps organizations apply data science and AI methods, including simulation, to design and improve their supply chain. Prior to founding Data Driven Supply Chain, I worked as an Operations Research Scientist at Target, designing e-commerce supply chain networks, and at General Mills, designing warehousing networks. I have used R for supply chain analytics for over eight years at these companies. I live in the Minneapolis, MN area and love running in the (usually cool) Minnesota air. I can be reached at [masked]

title: Portland R User Group: aggregate: meet, greet, learn, collaborate  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Hey folks, we were off last month but aggregate is back for July. This meetup will be online but we are discussing the potential return to in-person meetups so be on the lookup for those at a future date.

Please join us for the 42nd R aggRegate meetup on Zoom! We welcome current or aspiring R users who have any level of experience with the R programming language.

Our goal is to exchange knowledge, learn new skills, help each other troubleshoot coding problems, and meet new fellow R users.

No topic is off limits, and you may attend even if you don‚Äôt feel that you have anything to share. Come learn with us!

When: Wednesday, July 21st, 2021 @ 6:30-8 PM

Where: Online: zoom info provided soon (provided after you join).

Details: Marley Buchman will lead a discussion and present a demo of a Shiny app with persistent data. Typically Shiny apps are developed in a way in which the state of the app resets every time the app is accessed. Some applications would benefit from being able to save the state of the app upon exiting, and we will walk through one approach in doing that.

Agenda:

‚Ä¢ Marley's short demonstration of persistent data storage in Shiny

‚Ä¢ Brief intro/R project or problem: We'll take turns talking about an R project we're working on, a data/data-science problem, or something we want to learn, etc.

‚Ä¢ Next, anyone can share some code they've been working on and want help with / want feedback on. Make sure to have this ready before the meeting.

‚Ä¢ Before arriving, use the pdxrlang/aggregate GitHub repository to discuss ideas for things to work on at aggregate - https://github.com/pdxrlang/aggregate/issues

Please note that this event, like all PDX R events, adheres to the PDX R Code of Conduct: https://pdxrlang.com/code-of-conduct.html We are dedicated to a safe learning environment to all.

If you have any trouble message Marley Buchman in in the Meetup app, or on Twitter at @pdxrlang

title: Barcelona R User Group: Online event BerlinRUG: A long-short Bayesian State-Space model w/ R and RStan  [Virtual] , Spain, Europe
description:
Hello everyone! We would like to invite you to join a fellow R group event organised online. Please see event details below:
----------------------------------------------

Original Meetup: https://www.meetup.com/Berlin-R-Users-Group/events/278030316/

Welcome to our 2nd own Berlin RUG online meetup! We'll learn about bayesian modeling for a forecast on our upcoming election. And we will get to see each other again, so we're hoping many will sign up :)

A long-short Bayesian State-Space model for the German Federal Election 2021 with R and RStan

# Description
Marcus Gro√ü and Michelle Golchert will present a Bayesian model for forecasting the German federal election 2021 with R and RStan that gives more insights and more accurate predictions compared to simple poll-averaging methods. The model consists of two parts:
A model for the election outcome (i.e. the vote share for each party based on poll data) and a model to assign a probability to the coalition of the actual government using expert survey data. An in-depth description and motivation is discussed in this talk. The model is fitted with (R)Stan, a Bayesian modeling framework, that can seamlessly be integrated into R.

# Agenda
18:30 Intro
18:35 Talk
19:05 Q&A
19:30 Closing remarks (we can extend it if needed)

# Bios
Marcus Gro√ü and Michelle Golchert are Data Scientists at INWT Statistics.
Marcus holds a Ph.D. in Statistics and has several years experience consulting on and managing projects in the data science field. He is an expert in predictive analytics and Bayesian statistics.
Michelle has a master's degree in psychology and specializes in supporting Data Science projects in the areas of software development, DevOps and CI.

title: R-Ladies Bari: Practicing Data Science: a Collection of Case Studies  [Virtual] , Italy, Europe
description:
Practicing Data Science: a Collection of Case Studies

In questo workshop vedremo alcuni dei progetti di analisi dei dati (o di intelligenza artificiale) a cui Rosaria Silipo, principal Data Scientist @KNIME, ha lavorato nel corso degli anni. Partendo dalla sua tesi di laurea a inizio anni 90 sull‚Äôanalisi dei battiti cardiaci nell‚ÄôECG con reti neurali feedforward fino alla creazione di rap songs con reti neurali basate su LSTMs di qualche anno fa; da un classico churn prediction con un decision tree di fine anni 90 ai recommendation engines degli anni 2000; dalla soluzione di un problema di demand prediction con analisi di serie temporali all‚Äôanalisi dei testi da social media; inseme ripercorrereremo l‚Äôevoluzione del data science nel tempo. Tutta l'esperienza che Rosaria ha riciclato via via, sviluppato di nuovo con KNIME, descritto in vari articoli, raccolto all‚Äôinterno di un libro sar√† condivisa nella community RLadies Italy.

Aneddoti? Forse qualcuno ‚Ä¶ ci dice Rosaria!
Non vediamo l'ora!

SPEAKER
Rosaria Silipo | PhD, principal Data Scientist @KNIME

Rosaria Silipo, PhD, principal data scientist ora in KNIME, amava i dati prima che diventassero 'big & deep data'. Ha trascorso oltre 25 anni lavorando nell'AI, nell'analisi predittiva e nell'apprendimento automatico presso Siemens, Viseca, Nuance Communications e consulenza privata. Condividendo la sua esperienza pratica in un'ampia gamma di settori e implementazioni, tra cui IoT, customer intelligence, servizi finanziari, social media e sicurezza informatica, Rosaria √® autrice di oltre 50 pubblicazioni tecniche, inclusi i suoi libri pi√π recenti: "Guide to Intelligent Data Science" (Springer ) e "Codeless Deep Learning with KNIME" (Packt).

Rosaria Silipo, PhD, principal data scientist now at KNIME, loved data before it was big and learning before it was deep. She has spent 25+ years in applied AI, predictive analytics and machine learning at Siemens, Viseca, Nuance Communications, and private consulting. Sharing her practical experience in a broad range of industries and deployments, including IoT, customer intelligence, financial services, social media, and cybersecurity, Rosaria has authored 50+ technical publications, including her recent books: "Guide to Intelligent Data Science" (Springer) and "Codeless Deep Learning with KNIME" (Packt).

title: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup: When Do We Actually Need Causal Inference?  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup
description:
Repeat speaker Sean Taylor returns in July to talk about causal inference.

Thank you to EcoHealth Alliance for providing the Zoom link.

Conversations during the meetup are encouraged in the monthly-meetup-chat channel in the nyhackr slack: https://nyhackr.org/slack.html

The same week as this meetup, July 14-16, we also have what has become the annual Bayes and Stan workshop, taught by Jonah Gabry, Scott Spencer and Rob Trangucci, with Andrew Gelman popping in. More information is at https://www.tickettailor.com/events/landeranalytics/505284.

Then September 9-10 the R Conference returns in-person (and virtual) with workshops on September 1! Find out more at https://rstats.ai/nyr/.

About the Talk:
Causal inference provides a useful toolkit for data scientists working in a wide variety of fields, but they may rightly wonder why it's needed and when it's most useful. In this talk, I tour a variety of data science applications and apply a causal inference lens to them. Framing problems using causal language yields interesting insights into the nature of the work we do as scientists, and helps sharpen the goals, requirements, and risks of our projects. We show that beyond the more standard applications like A/B testing, some data science tasks can (perhaps surprisingly) be described as estimating causal quantities, and how this changes our models and their predictions.

About Sean:
Sean J. Taylor is a staff data scientist at Lyft's Rideshare Labs team, where he works on causal inference, experimentation, forecasting, and structural modeling. Previously, he led the applied statistics team in Facebook‚Äôs Core Data Science team. He earned his PhD in Information Systems from NYU‚Äôs Stern School of Business as well as a BS in Economics from Wharton School. He specializes in using machine learning, statistics, and randomized experiments for measurement, forecasting, and policy decisions. Sean‚Äôs research spans a wide range of topics: online social influence, social networks, applied statistics, causal inference, and Bayesian modeling. He is also an avid engineer who enjoys putting research into practice by building software, such as his forecasting library Prophet.

The talk will begin at 7 PM EDT and we will start admitting people to the event shortly before. Since this is completely remote there will be no pizza but everyone is encouraged to have pizza individually.

title: R-Ladies Vancouver: Focus on Content: Create Enterprise-Worthy Shiny Applications with Periscope   [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
The periscope R package is a framework that you can use to significantly speed up your shiny development ‚Äì whether you are just writing your first collaborative application or taking on a bigger project that will be deployed to many users. Periscope can significantly "up" your Shiny game by jump-starting development in a way that is flexible and robust. This lets you focus on the content of your application, as opposed to the mechanics (and those insidious pitfalls!) of building a shiny application for multiple users.

Speaker Bio:
Dr. Connie Brett is the CEO, Founder, and Principal Data Scientist of Aggregate Genius Inc. located in BC, Canada. She is experienced in using many types of models and algorithms as well as architecting cutting-edge big-data analytics-integrated platforms. She has submitted publications and patents; contributes to and maintains R packages and frameworks (such as periscope) in the open-source community; and attends and speaks at industry events. With over 20 years spent focusing on producing solid analytical models, software and visualization tools ‚Äì as well as custom IT solutions architecture ‚Äì she continues to carry forward her passion for helping clients realize true business insights from analytics.

title: R-Ladies Philly: July Workshop: Mapping COVID-19 Vaccination Across the US  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
The goal of this workshop is to provide a hands-on introduction on how to display your data onto relevant geographic locations in a map (e.g. continent, state) using the ggplot2 package in R. Attendees will learn to create a mapped visualization of current up-to-date vaccination rates across states in the US.

Attendees with all skill levels are welcome to attend! We recommend that participants actively follow along on their computers. This will require having R and RStudio installed and basic knowledge of R commands and the RStudio IDE (https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/). Several packages are required. Please install the following packages ahead of time or sign up for an RStudio Cloud account (https://login.rstudio.cloud/register). Packages that will be used: "tidyverse", "ggplot2", "reader", "maps", "viridis", "choroplethr", and "choroplethrMaps".

About the Speaker:
Michelle is a graduate student in the Cognition and Neuroscience PhD Program at Temple University. She received her bachelor‚Äôs degree in Cognitive Neuroscience from Johns Hopkins University in 2014 and continued to earn her master‚Äôs degree in Human Development at Cornell University in 2017. Her research broadly looks at digital media and risky decision making using a behavioral and neuroimaging approach. In her free time, she enjoys exploring the Philly food scene and practicing yoga!

title: R-Ladies Sydney: DIY R Package  [Virtual] , Australia, Australia
description:
Do you have a few custom functions on heavy rotation? Perhaps you have a piece of code that you regularly share with colleagues? Maybe you want to include your analysis code alongside a publication? Why not put it all in an R package?!

This interactive workshop will equip you with the basic skills to create an R package of your own!

Participants should have
1) a Github account;
2) the most recent version of R and RStudio installed;
3) the following package(s) and their dependencies installed: devtools, testthat, knitr.

Bio: Fonti is a postdoctoral research fellow at University of New South Wales, Sydney, Australia. She is an evolutionary biologist at heart but is currently working as an R package developer. Fonti works alongside researchers to develop R software tools for the research community. Her interests include biostatistics, reproducible science, learning about the latest coding practices and teaching others to enjoy using R. She is the founder of UNSWcodeRs - a university R user community where students and staff can learn new skills and find coding support.

title: R-Ladies Freiburg: From messy data to beautiful plot: Guided TidyTuesday  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
Know the basics of data wrangling but want some hands-on practice? Want to learn ggplot tips and tricks to make your plots eye-catching? Seen cool visualizations on Twitter but find it hard to go from messy dataset to beautiful visualization?

In this monthly meetup, we‚Äôll go through a Tidy Tuesday dataset together step-by-step, walking you through the entire process from coming up with an interesting question to asnwer, getting the data in the right format and finally, creating a cool visualization!

You may have heard of Tidy Tuesday -- a weekly initiative by R for Data Science which provides a new dataset every week for the community to practice wrangling and visualizing. It has a huge Twitter community and is one of the best ways to practice and develop tidyverse skills, whether you‚Äôre still reviewing the basics or have quite the repertoire. This series has something for everyone and is especially designed to be beginner friendly!

It's important to us to ensure that Guided Tidy Tuesday is a safe space for gender minorities and especially those who are just starting out with R. Studies have shown that letting gender minorities speak first promotes a welcoming and supportive atmosphere for underrepresented groups. All are welcome at this meetup but we specifically ask cisgender men to take a passive role in this meetup and hold comments / questions until after others have had the chance to ask. Thank you for your support!

title: R-Ladies Freiburg: First steps on Git using R-Studio and Github  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
During this workshop we will introduce the concept of version control using Git, RStudio and GiHub. We will learn the basic Git commands and how to use them directly from R-Studio. I will show how to link your R-Projects with GitHub to create online repositories to share your work and how it can be used for collaboration. At the end I will do a short demo on uploading a small WebPage to Github such as the one from R-Ladies Seattle

https://github.com/rladies-seattle/rladies-seattle-organizing

If you have some time to prepare before the Meetup I would recommend you to:

¬∑ create a GitHub account (if you do not have one yet) on https://github.com/

¬∑ download and install Git from https://git-scm.com/

For the last part of the meetup some very basic knowledge or markdown/Rmarkdown in recommended, but not mandatory, we will also go through it. If you want, you can have a look to the first 35 minutes of this video about RMarkdown: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H91WSwALx1A

title: AthensR: A long-short Bayesian State-Space model with R and RStan (Berlin RUG #45)  [Virtual] , Greece, Europe
description:
Welcome to our 2nd own Berlin RUG online meetup! We'll learn about bayesian modeling for a forecast on our upcoming election. And we will get to see each other again, so we're hoping many will sign up :)

A long-short Bayesian State-Space model for the German Federal Election 2021 with R and RStan

# Description
Marcus Gro√ü and Michelle Golchert will present a Bayesian model for forecasting the German federal election 2021 with R and RStan that gives more insights and more accurate predictions compared to simple poll-averaging methods. The model consists of two parts:
A model for the election outcome (i.e. the vote share for each party based on poll data) and a model to assign a probability to the coalition of the actual government using expert survey data. An in-depth description and motivation is discussed in this talk. The model is fitted with (R)Stan, a Bayesian modeling framework, that can seamlessly be integrated into R.

# Agenda
19:30 Intro
19:35 Talk
20:05 Q&A
20:30 Closing remarks (we can extend it if needed)

# Bios
Marcus Gro√ü and Michelle Golchert are Data Scientists at INWT Statistics.
Marcus holds a Ph.D. in Statistics and has several years experience consulting on and managing projects in the data science field. He is an expert in predictive analytics and Bayesian statistics.
Michelle has a master's degree in psychology and specializes in supporting Data Science projects in the areas of software development, DevOps and CI.

title: R-Ladies Barcelona: Paseo aleatorio por la programaci√≥n (en femenino) + El ingenio (in)visible  [Virtual] , Spain, Europe
description:
¬°Bienvenidas al meetup virtual de junio! En esta ocasi√≥n tenemos dos charlas por Nat√†lia Vilor-Tejedor y N√∫ria Sal√°n. No nos hablar√°n de R, sino de mujeres cientificas!

"Paseo aleatorio por la programaci√≥n (en femenino)" por Nat√†lia Vilor Tejedor (@natvilortejedor): ~ 15 minutos

"El ingenio (in)visible" N√∫ria Sal√°n (@nuriasalann): ~ 45 minutos

*Recordad que para acceder a la charla necesitar√©is una contrase√±a que os enviaremos 1 hora antes del evento.

A continuaci√≥n os dejamos la descripci√≥n de las charlas y las biograf√≠as de las speakers. ¬°Nos vemos pronto!

--------------------------------------
Nat√†lia Vilor Tejedor (@natvilortejedor): "Paseo aleatorio por la programaci√≥n (en femenino)" ~ 15 minutos

Biograf√≠a:
"
Natalia Vilor-Tejedor is a Postdoctoral Research Scientist at BarcelonaBeta Brain Research Center (BBRC), the Center for Genomic Regulation (CRG) and the Erasmus University Medical Center (EMC). Moreover, Natalia collaborates in teaching activities as an Assistant Professor in the Department of Mathematics at the Autonomous University of Barcelona (UAB), and in the Department of Systems Biology at the University of Vic (UVIC-UCC). She conducted her PhD thesis in the Biomedicine program of Pompeu Fabra University (UPF) at the Barcelona Institute of Global Health (ISGlobal). Her main interests include statistical methods and analytical strategies in Neurogenetics and Imaging Genetics.
LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/nat%C3%A0lia-vilor-tejedor-47aa0a66/
"

----------------------------------------
N√∫ria Sal√°n (@nuriasalann): "El ingenio (in)visible" ~ 45 minutos

Inventoras que no salen en los libros de texto, nombres de mujeres que han hecho, consus inventos y descubrimientos, que nuestra vida sea m√°s f√°cil, m√°s c√≥moda, m√°s amable... pero siguen siendo desconocidas. En cambio, los nombres de los inventores salen en los libros y son visibles. Charla para dar visibilidad a todas esas ingeniosas/ingenieras/inventoras desconocidas pero que forman parte de nuestra historia.

Biograf√≠a:
"
Profesora de metalurgia en la ESEIAAT (UPC-Terrassa), y presidenta de la Societat Catalana de Tecnolog√≠a, he dedicado las dos √∫ltimas d√©cadas a rescatar nombres y viencias de mujeres de todas las √©pocas y lugares para hacerlas visibles y que puedan tener el reconocimiento que merecen. As√≠, aunque mantengo mi perfil t√©cnico, mi actividad personal y profesional, √∫ltimamente, est√° m√°s relacionada con mostrar la cara m√°s humana (y femenina) de la tecnolog√≠a. Curiosidades sobre mi: soy forjadora aficinada, pastelera aficionada y novelista aficionada. Y con aficionada quiero decir que lo hago (creo) bien, pero no me dedico profesionalmente.
"

title: R-Ladies Washington D.C.: R for Data Science Book Club (Meeting 1)  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
R-Ladies DC will be reading R for Data Science in 8 biweekly meetings (July 15, July 29, Aug 12, Aug 26, Sept 9, Sept 23, Oct 14, Oct 28).

The selected book chapters should be read before the meeting time.

There are also exercises for each week which you should aim to complete before the meeting as well. We'll go through solutions to the exercises as a group. In most weeks, we'll also do some additional exercises from the chapters live during the meeting.

It's okay if you're not able to complete everything ahead of time, we understand that life happens. Please still attend the meeting, even if you didn't read everything or complete all the exercises.

In addition, if you have to miss a meeting time, all code will be made available after the meeting on Github: https://github.com/sctyner/r4ds-bookclub-rladiesdc

Note on the exercises: For all exercises, we will use the online version of the book. There are some differences between the online and print exercises, so we'll stick with the online ones so that everyone is doing the same exercises.

Note on meeting access: All meetings will be virtual. You must RSVP to the meeting on the R-Ladies DC Meetup page to receive the Zoom link. All meetings will take place on a Thursday from 7:00-8:30pm ET (America/New York).

Meeting 1 (July 15, 2021): Introductions to one another and to R & RStudio

Chapters to read:
Physical book chapters: Preface, Ch. 2: Workflow Basics, Ch. 4: Workflow Scripts, Ch. 6: Workflow Projects

title: R-Ladies Washington D.C.: Pandemics, Graphics, and Perception of Log Scales  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Abstract:
In 2020, there was suddenly worldwide interest in graphics on a level we don't normally see - people were checking news sites daily looking for graphs, maps, and any information about how the COVID pandemic was progressing over time. Along with this, there were some very novel forms of graphics, some of which worked and many of which did not. As the pandemic continued, however, most news organizations seemed to settle on certain categories of graphics for displaying COVID case counts, hospitalizations, and deaths. Watching the pandemic and the graphics explosion that resulted, I found relatively little research into how people perceive exponential growth, and even less research into the effectiveness of log scales for conveying information. I'll talk about a series of experiments that are currently under development to explore these two topics, as well as the evolution of graphics over the course of the pandemic.

Bio: Susan Vanderplas is an assistant professor in the Statistics Department at University of Nebraska, Lincoln, researching the perception of statistical charts and graphs. She also works with the Center for Statistical Applications in Forensic Evidence (CSAFE) at Iowa State University, developing statistical methods for examination of bullets, cartridges, and footwear.

In her spare time (hah) she likes to sew, cross-stitch mildly off-color sayings, and bake things (usually badly).

title: Dublin R: Why R? Webinar - "Julia for R-Lovers: Ideas for a Dual Language Workflow"  [Virtual] , Ireland, Europe
description:
Why R? Webinar: "Julia for R-Lovers: Ideas for a Dual Language Workflow"
with Kyla McConnell (PhD Student, University of Freiburg)

Julia for R-Lovers: Ideas for a dual-language workflow

Abstract
As a language for statistical processing, R excels in its wide variety of highly developed packages and its unrivaled visualization abilities (as well as its open and accepting community!) However,
the new kid on the block, the Julia language, has become a tempting rival; Julia promises to be easy-to-read and quick-to-adopt, but simultaneously impressively fast and powerful. Luckily, you don‚Äôt have to choose, because Julia and R are the perfect match, allowing you to use Julia for its power without abandoning the R features and packages you know and love.

In this demo, I‚Äôll show you an example of a dual-language workflow that includes the best of both worlds. In addition to the basics of the Julia environment, I‚Äôll walk you through an example of using Julia together with the best parts of R. Specifically, I‚Äôll show how to go from exploring a dataset in familiar R syntax to fitting complex models in Julia that would be very slow or fail to fit in R, to visualizing your results in R without leaving your Julia environment!

This basic introduction is meant to address beginners who are firmly rooted in R. We will not cover installing Julia on your computer or get you completely ready to go in Julia. Rather, the demo is intended to spark ideas for a R - Julia workflow and get you excited to discover more about Julia!

Bio
Kyla McConnell is a Ph.D. student in quantitative psycholinguistics at the University of Freiburg in Freiburg, Germany. In her work modeling individual differences in reading times of predictable phrases, she has recently adopted an R - Julia - R workflow for fitting statistical and machine learning models. An outspoken tidyverse and ggplot2 fan, she is co-organizer of R-Ladies Freiburg (https://www.meetup.com/rladies-freiburg/) as well as a local R-stats group for linguists. For her introduction to Julia for statistical modeling, she‚Äôs especially grateful to the instructors of the Potsdam Summer School on Statistical Methods for Linguistics and Psychology (https://vasishth.github.io/smlp2021/).

title: R-Ladies Seattle: Dimensionality Reduction Tutorial: PCA & UMAP  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Please join us for a lunchtime R-Ladies meetup with Anabel Ruggiero. Anabel will guide us through a tutorial on dimensionality reduction. Dimensionality reduction is a useful technique for data visualization and as an initial layer of a model. This makes it a powerful tool in a data scientist's arsenal.

Anabel will go over the basics of the math and algorithms behind PCA, and UMAP. Most of the time will be devoted to an R example implementing these algorithms.

-- About Anabel --

Anabel Ruggiero is an unaffiliated researcher whose interests lie in the intersection of applied mathematics and software engineering. She received her doctorate in Chemical Engineering at Oklahoma State University, where she did research in the field of computational biosystems. Her current project is NNDescent.cpp, a reimplementation of and iteration upon PyNNDescent. This project is an entry in The Billion-Scale Approximate Nearest Neighbor Search Challenge hosted by NeurIPS 2021.

LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/anabel-ruggiero-138372114/
Github: https://github.com/AnabelSMRuggiero

-- How to follow Anabel‚Äôs tutorial --

Please find the presentation and associated GitHub repo here. **If you want to follow the full tutorial, please fork the repo and be ready to run the code**:
https://github.com/AnabelSMRuggiero/Dimensionality-Reduction-Tutorial

This tutorial will require the uwot and ggplot2 packages to be installed in R.
uwot: https://github.com/jlmelville/uwot
ggplot2: https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2

If you want to watch the presentation and not run the code in real time, that is also fine.

Please reach out if you have any questions (email: [masked]).

-- Additional resources --

Principal Component Analysis: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Principal_component_analysis
How UMAP Works: https://umap-learn.readthedocs.io/en/latest/how_umap_works.html
TSNE vs UMAP: https://towardsdatascience.com/tsne-vs-umap-global-structure-4d8045acba17
UMAP: Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection for Dimension Reduction: https://arxiv.org/abs/1802.03426
Matrix Computations: http://math.ecnu.edu.cn/~jypan/Teaching/books/2013%20Matrix%20Computations%204th.pdf

title: R-Ladies Dallas: Dr. Pratheepa Jeganathan: R/Bioconductor for Molecular microbial data analysis  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
For the July 12 edition of our R-Ladies Dallas webinar series, we are excited to welcome Dr. Pratheepa Jeganathan as our guest speaker. Dr. Jeganathan will share how she is using R and Bioconductor packages for molecular microbial data analysis.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Session title: Molecular microbial data analysis
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Abstract: High-throughput sequencing generates massive molecular microbial datasets that pose several statistical challenges. As a result, statistical methods have been developed to address contamination sequences from reagents, unequal sampling, unbounded and undetected taxa, sparsity, and heterogeneity. I will talk about some of the statistical methods in molecular microbial data analysis and demonstrate the methods using a plant microbiome dataset and R/Bioconductor packages. This talk is based on A Statistical Perspective on the Challenges in Molecular Microbial Biology published in Jeganathan and Holmes (2021). The workÔ¨Çow is available at https://pratheepaj.github.io/diÔ¨ÄTop/.

Bio:
Dr. Pratheepa Jeganathan is an Assistant Professor in the Department of Mathematics and Statistics at McMaster University. Pratheepa's research focuses on addressing challenges in multi-domain data analysis. Her research team uses, extends, and develops statistical methods and computational tools to analyze microbiome multi-omic and spatial multi-omic data in R/Bioconductor, including topic analysis, hierarchical modeling, Bayesian statistics, multivariate statistics, bootstrap method, spatial statistics, and approximation theory in statistics. Currently, Pratheepa teaches undergraduate and graduate courses in statistics and data science.

Before joining McMaster University, Pratheepa completed postdoctoral training in the Department of Statistics at Stanford University.
She received a Ph.D. in Mathematics with an emphasis in Statistics and MS in Statistics from Texas Tech University. While completing her Ph.D., she interned at the Research and Testing Laboratory in Lubbock and the Clinical Research Institute at Texas Tech Health Sciences Center. She received a B.Sc.in Statistics and Operations Research from the University of Peradeniya in Sri Lanka. She taught undergraduate courses at Stanford University, Texas Tech University, and the University of Peradeniya in Sri Lanka.

Twitter: https://twitter.com/PratheepaJ

Website: https://pratheepaj.github.io/

In questo workshop vedremo alcuni dei progetti di analisi dei dati (o di intelligenza artificiale) a cui Rosaria Silipo, principal Data Scientist @KNIME, ha lavorato nel corso degli anni. Partendo dalla sua tesi di laurea a inizio anni 90 sull‚Äôanalisi dei battiti cardiaci nell‚ÄôECG con reti neurali feedforward fino alla creazione di rap songs con reti neurali basate su LSTMs di qualche anno fa; da un classico churn prediction con un decision tree di fine anni 90 ai recommendation engines degli anni 2000; dalla soluzione di un problema di demand prediction con analisi di serie temporali all‚Äôanalisi dei testi da social media; inseme ripercorrereremo l‚Äôevoluzione del data science nel tempo. Tutta l'esperienza che Rosaria ha riciclato via via, sviluppato di nuovo con KNIME, descritto in vari articoli, raccolto all‚Äôinterno di un libro sar√† condivisa nella community RLadies Italy.

Rosaria Silipo | PhD, principal Data Scientist @KNIME

Rosaria Silipo, PhD, principal data scientist ora in KNIME, amava i dati prima che diventassero 'big & deep data'. title: R-Ladies New York: The Epidemiologist R Handbook  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
For our July event, we are excited to host authors Neale Batra, Aminata Ndiaye, and Paula Blomquist, who will present the Epidemiologist R Handbook, a free new code reference book targeted to R users working in applied epidemiology and public health, but handy for anyone.

This event will be hosted over Zoom, and the link will be available on this Meetup page at noon on the day of the event.

Agenda (times approximate):
7-7:05 pm: R-Ladies NYC Announcements
7:05-7:50: "The Epidemiologist R Handbook - a new resource for public health practitioners (and everyone else)"
7:50-8:15: Questions and wrap-up

Abstract: Amidst the COVID-19 pandemic, 50 epidemiologists from across the world joined forces seeking to improve access to R and elevate the quality of analytics in public health. Writing in their spare time, they produced The Epidemiologist R Handbook (epiRhandbook.com), a free new code reference book targeted to R users working in applied epidemiology and public health, but handy for anyone. The "Epi R Handbook" is full of code snippets and tutorials addressing day-to-day data cleaning, analysis, visualization, reporting, and collaboration challenges. The handbook also comes in an offline version for use in settings with low internet connectivity. Since its launch, the handbook has been used 200,000 times by 36,000 people in 203 countries/territories. In this session, founder Neale Batra is joined by co-authors Paula Blomquist and Aminata Ndiaye to discuss the handbook's utility for you, the intersection of R and public health, the project's next steps, and the editorial and technical challenges they faced creating this resource for the community.

Bio:
Neale Batra is the founder and editor of the Epidemiologist R Handbook project. As an applied epidemiologist, he tries to leverage R to better inform decision-making in health emergencies. Currently he works for the COVID-19 analytics team at the World Health Organization (Geneva), but has previously worked internationally for Doctors without Borders and in the US for the public health departments of Philadelphia and Santa Clara County. He loves teaching, and in his spare time enjoys guiding rock climbing and backpacking trips.

Paula Blomquist is an epidemiologist in Public Health England, where she works on the national surveillance of COVID-19. She spends much of her day job creating data visualisations and R markdown reports to monitor variants, with a particular fondness of {patchwork} and {flextable}. Paula has also used R for analyses in international deployments, most recently with the UK Emergency Medical Team to Samoa during the 2019 measles epidemic. Paula is a contributor to the Epidemiologist R Handbook, and excited to encourage more people in public health to learn to code.

Aminata NDIAYE is a Biostatistician at Epicentre Research Department-MSF (Doctors without Borders). She graduated from Paris Descartes University School of Medicine in Public health and from Paris Saclay University School of Sciences in Bioinformatics and Biostatistics. She previously worked at World Health Organization (WHO) as an analyst during the 10th Ebola virus disease (EVD) outbreak in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) and at Karolinska Institute‚Äôs department of medical epidemiology and biostatistics as a Research assistant. She is co-organizer and member of the R-ladies Stockholm group since its creation, in 2018.
---

R-Ladies is dedicated to providing a harassment-free experience for everyone. We do not tolerate harassment of participants in any form. Please take a moment to review the R-Ladies Global code of conduct (particularly if this is your first time attending!): https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct

title: R-Ladies New York: Creating model en mass with workflowsets  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
For our second July event, we are excited to host Max Kuhn of RStudio who will be presenting on the workflowsets package.

This event will be hosted over Zoom, and the link will be available on this Meetup page at noon on the day of the event.

Agenda (times approximate):
7-7:05 pm: R-Ladies NYC Announcements
7:05-7:50: "Creating model en mass with workflowsets"
7:50-8:15: Questions and wrap-up

Abstract: The tidymodels packages allow users to create and optimize models and their pre-processing steps (e.g. PCA, feature encodings, etc). With new data, it is common to try a variety of models to determine what works best. The workflowsets package enables users to easily evaluate, rank, and even combine (with the stacks package) myriad combinations of models and pre-processors.

Bio: Max Kuhn is a software engineer at RStudio. He is currently working on improving R's modeling capabilities. He was a Senior Director of Nonclinical Statistics at Pfizer Global R&D in Connecticut. He was applying models in the pharmaceutical and diagnostic industries for over 18 years. Max has a Ph.D. in Biostatistics.

Max is the author of R packages for techniques in machine learning and reproducible research. He, and Kjell Johnson, wrote the book Applied Predictive Modeling, which won the Ziegel award from the American Statistical Association, which recognizes the best book reviewed in Technometrics in 2015. Their latest book, Feature Engineering and Selection, was published in 2019.
---

title: Newcastle Upon Tyne Data Science Meetup: July Meet-up  [Virtual] , United Kingdom, Europe
group: Newcastle Upon Tyne Data Science Meetup
description:
Zaynaib Giwa (https://www.linkedin.com/in/zaynaib-ola-giwa/)

Title: D3 for R users

Abstract:

D3 is an amazing data visualization library that allows you to create
highly customizable visualizations. But with that flexibility, comes a
high learning curve. In this workshop, I will be teaching 3 basic
concepts to create any chart with D3. These concepts are SVGs, data
binding, and scales. When you understand these fundamentals you will
be able to use your d3 scripts with your R shiny apps through the r2d3
R package.

I‚Äôm excited to teach you about the foundations of working with D3.js.

title: SoCal R Users Group (SoCal RUG): Book club  - OpenIntro Statistics  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Are you looking to improve your statistical skills? Come just us for a book club. It will be headed up by John Peach and Carey Huh. The idea is to motivate us to read books and discussing them together. This will help all of us to develop our skills.

The format will be that the leader will prepare a short summary of the material and present it to the group. We will then discuss the material and do some exercises.

The expectations are that you will attend regularly. If you cannot make a commitment to attend, please wait until the next book club starts. It is also expected that participants will take turns being the leader. The leader should prepare a summary of the material that was read and present it to the group.

We will meet each week, Tuesday evening between 6:30 and 8:00 PM for eight or more weeks.

Book: Title: OpenIntro Statistics, 4th Ed.
Online: https://www.openintro.org/book/os/
Dead Tree: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1943450072/

Signing up: When you sign-up you will be placed on the waiting list. We always have a lot of interest but the book club is a significant commitment. The coordinator will confirm your commitment. Please make sure that you get meet-up emails.

Session 1:
* C1: Introduction to data
* C2: Summarizing data
* Exercise

Session 2:
* C3: Probability
* Exercise

Session 3:
* C4: Distributions of random variables
* Exercise

Session 4:
* C5: Foundations for inference
* Exercise

Session 5:
* C6: Inference for categorical data
* Exercise

Session 6:
* C7: Inference for numerical data
* Exercise

Session 7:
* C8: Introduction to linear regression
* Exercise

Session 8:
* C9: Multiple and logistic regression
* Exercise

title: Central Iowa R User Group: R and Python study group, United States, US/Canada
description:
Until we can meet again in person, please join our Slack workspace to stay in touch, ask questions, and share information throughout the week.

https://join.slack.com/t/centraliowarusergroup/shared_invite/zt-dhfa5ude-0tvHascxRkn2pgiqDdQgrw

The Slack workspace is available any time, not just Saturday mornings.

Are you tired of learning and playing with Python and R alone? Would you like to get together with a few friends and learn together? I have been starting to learn R and Python for data science and following the typical route of videos and practice projects. I really want to ramp up my learning and exposure to different ways. Here is my proposal:

- Gather a small group of 2-5 and learn together.
- Meet at a coffee shop, library, or some other space that has Wi-Fi.
- Pick a project, data set or problem, then work to solve it with different tools.
- Keep it fluid and informal.
- Meet on a regular basis, say weekly to start, and adjust as needed.
- Aim to keep the meetings 2-4 hours long, but this can be adjusted to the project or group. People can come and go as needed.
- It does not have to be the same people each time, so you only have to commit to going once to check it out.

Are you interested? Show up at the meeting spot, have some coffee, meet new friends and bring a project or question.

- Gather a small group of 2-5 and learn together.

title: Montreal R User Group: [Webinar] Accurate Table Extraction from Documents & Images with Spark OCR  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
REGISTER HERE: https://events.johnsnowlabs.com/accurate-table-extraction-from-documents-images-with-spark-ocr

Extracting data formatted as a table (tabular data) is a common task ‚Äî whether you‚Äôre analyzing financial statements, academic research papers, or clinical trial documentation. Table-based information varies heavily in appearance, fonts, borders, and layouts. This makes the data extraction task challenging even when the text is searchable ‚Äì but more so when the table is only available as an image.

This webinar presents how Spark OCR automatically extract tabular data from images. This end-to-end solution includes computer vision models for table detection and table structure recognition, as well as OCR models for extracting text & numbers from each cell. The implemented approach provides state-of-the-art accuracy for the ICDAR 2013 and TableBank benchmark datasets.

REGISTER HERE: https://events.johnsnowlabs.com/accurate-table-extraction-from-documents-images-with-spark-ocr

title: Montreal R User Group: DSSVirtual | Retail & Ecommerce  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
Register: https://info.datascience.salon/crossing-the-ai-valley-of-death-deploying-monitoring-models-in-production

It‚Äôs happened again. You built another AI model that will never see the light of day because it won‚Äôt make it past the AI ‚Äúvalley of death‚Äù ‚Äì the crossover of model development to model deployment across your enterprise. The handoff between data science and engineering teams is fraught with friction, outstanding questions around governance and accountability, and who is responsible for different parts of the pipeline and process. Even worse? The patchwork approach when building an AI pipeline leaves many organizations open to risks because of a lack of a holistic approach to security and monitoring.

Join us to learn about approaches and solutions for configuring a ModelOps pipeline that‚Äôs right for your organization. You‚Äôll discover why it‚Äôs never too early to plan for operationalization of models, regardless of whether your organization has 1, 10, 100, or 1,000 models in production.

The discussion will also reveal the merits of an open container specification that allows you to easily package and deploy models in production from everywhere. Finally, new approaches for monitoring model drift and explainability will be revealed that will help manage expectations with business leaders all through a centralized AI software platform called Modzy¬Æ.

Register: https://info.datascience.salon/crossing-the-ai-valley-of-death-deploying-monitoring-models-in-production

title: Salt Lake City R Users Group: Create infographics with R  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: Salt Lake City R Users Group
description:
Our August Meetup will be a remote gathering; the Zoom link will be posted the week of the event.

Infographics are everywhere, and when well-designed can be a fantastic way of sharing data highlights in an engaging and visually appealing way to non-technical audiences. Typically infographics are custom made by a graphic designer who has been provided the numbers that will be represented in the graphic, and therefore can be time-intensive to produce. Producing more than one infographic of the same design to display different values (for instance, for different geographical areas) has a linear increase in production time for each n+1 graphic once the basic design time has been accounted for. This talk will describe a novel method for producing infographics using R that allows for dynamically adjusting the graphical elements based on any number of data values and rapidly producing bespoke versions. A walkthrough of the process used to create 3,142 custom infographics (one for each county in the US) will be presented to illustrate the process.

Jonathan Zadra, PhD is a Director of Data Science at the non-profit Sorenson Impact Center in Salt Lake City, Utah. He combines his skills in statistics, programming, and data visualization with expertise in data privacy and policy to empower governments, nonprofits, and philanthropists working in a wide array of issue areas. His areas of focus include criminal justice data (including work with the PEW Charitable Trusts, Utah Department of Corrections, Utah Indigent Defense Commission, and Utah Commission on Criminal and Juvenile Justice), early- and higher-education data including a multi-year project supported by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, as well as other issue areas like homelessness or poverty, and has worked on many smaller projects building evaluations and impact measurements for a variety of social-good non-profits around the country. He received his doctorate from the University of Virginia, where he studied cognitive science and neuroscience and designed and conducted rigorous RCTs - and also fell in love with R way back in 2006!

title: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup: tidyquery and queryparser: Translating SQL Queries to dplyr Pipelines  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup
description:
This month we look at the intersection of R and SQL.

Thank you to EcoHealth Alliance for providing the Zoom link.

Conversations during the meetup are encouraged in the monthly-meetup-chat channel in the nyhackr slack: https://nyhackr.org/slack.html

The R Conference returns in-person (and virtual) September 9-10 with workshops on September 1! Find out more at https://rstats.ai/nyr/.

About the Talk:
The R package {tidyquery} runs SQL queries on R data frames. To do this, it uses the R package {queryparser} to translate SQL queries into R expressions, then uses {dplyr} to evaluate these expressions. In this talk, I'll describe the reasons for creating {tidyquery} and {queryparser} and compare them to several other packages with related goals, including {sqldf} and {dbplyr}. I'll also discuss the broader theme of "syntaxes for data manipulation"‚Äîhow they differ across languages, packages, and frameworks and what other efforts are underway to loosen the tight coupling of these syntaxes to the compute engines they control.

About Ian:
Ian Cook is the director of developer relations at Ursa Computing, where he promotes and contributes to the Apache Arrow project. Previously he worked as a machine learning educator at Cloudera and a data scientist at TIBCO and AMD. He is the author of several R packages and the creator of the popular Coursera course ‚ÄúAnalyzing Big Data with SQL.‚Äù Ian is a co-founder of Research Triangle Analysts, the largest data science meetup group in the Raleigh, North Carolina, area. He received a masters degree in statistics from Lehigh University.

The talk will begin at 7 PM EDT and we will start admitting people to the event shortly before. Since this is completely remote there will be no pizza but everyone is encouraged to have pizza individually.

title: R-Ladies Philly: Causal Inference with R  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Across public health, medicine, and social and behavioral sciences, researchers aim to answer causal questions. However, inferences about causation are challenging and require several assumptions to draw unbiased causal effects from observational data. This workshop discusses the difference between association and causation and introduces various methods to infer causal effects with observational data. We will then study R packages that implement propensity score techniques to estimate an average treatment effect ‚Äì such as matching, subclassification, and inverse probability weighting. The workshop also provides several implementation options depending on the data type and the target causal effects of interest.

About our speaker:

Youjin Lee is an Assistant Professor in the Department of Biostatistics at the Brown School of Public Health. Her research focuses on developing causal inference methods with complex data where standard assumptions are often violated. She published R packages for causal inference with social network data and multilevel settings. Originally from South Korea, Youjin received her Ph.D. in Biostatistics from Johns Hopkin University. Before joining Brown University, she did her postdoctoral training at the University of Pennsylvania.

Tidy Tuesday (https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday) is a social weekly event where you can practice you data wrangling and visualisation skills using real-world data in a safe and supportive forum! Every Tuesday a new dataset is released.

*Who is going to present?
This is not a presentation. Please expect a hands-on session in a friendly and laid-back atmosphere where we are all encouraged to learn together. On the night, we will use the dataset released on Tuesday July 27th, divide into groups, and work and learn together to produce interesting visualisations. This will be an opportunity to work on real-world data in a collaborative environment, as well as to practice sharing your code on GitHub and with the online Twitter community.

* When are we meeting?
The hands-on will start at 5:30 pm for 1.5 hour. Please arrive on time! After the coding part we can have a social event for the last 30 minutes, and show each other what we achieved. End time 7:30 pm.

title: R-Ladies Utrecht: Growing into the R community  [Virtual] , Netherlands, Europe
description:
The workshop is a joint event with R-Ladies Coventry (UK) and will be led by Dr Shannon Pileggi (https://www.pipinghotdata.com/about.html)! Shannon is currently a Statistician at Adelphi Research in Doylestown, PA.

"Starting something new in R can be daunting, but there are many community resources that can help! In this presentation, I‚Äôll discuss how I crafted a job interview presentation by making modifications on publicly available TidyTuesday code. This built the technical and confidence-boosting scaffolding I needed for more open-ended projects. The success of this experience inspired me to transition from my role as a consumer and creator to contributor to give back to the R community, which has been incredibly fulfilling. Despite social distancing, I feel more connected to the R community than ever before!"

PREPARATION AND RESOURCES
There is nothing to prepare in advance. The resources for the workshop are available here: https://github.com/shannonpileggi/growing-into-r

ONLINE PROGRAMME
The event will be held online and will start at 19:00 (Netherlands time). Please join us via the Zoom link (visible to attendees)

CODE OF CONDUCT
Please take a minute to read our code of conduct - we are committed to creating a safe and harassment-free environment:
https://github.com/rladies/.github/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

R-Ladies events are always free and open to anyone who wants to participate as long as they follow the code of conduct. We are pro-actively inclusive of queer, trans, and all minority identities, with additional sensitivity to intersectional identities. Our priority is to provide a safe community space for anyone identifying as a minority gender who is interested in and/or working with R.

title: R-Ladies Freiburg: Colour your ggplots beautiful!  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
Struggling with boring black and white plots? Sick of R's default colours? We've got your back! In this meetup, we'll show you how to colour your ggplots beautiful.

We'll cover:
- how to use any custom colour(s) you fancy (and how to find colours that match perfectly)
- commonly used colour palettes like viridis and RColorBrewer, but also lesser-known options that are based on e.g. Wes Anderson films, US National Park posters, or classic rock album covers
- things to consider when creating data visualisations, such as how to make sure your graphs are accessible and don't perpetuate (gender) stereotypes

So join us to play with color in ggplot and never have a bland plot again!

It's important to us to ensure that R-Ladies Freiburg events are a safe space for gender minorities and especially those who are just starting out with R. All are welcome at this meetup but we specifically ask cisgender men to take a passive role in this meetup and hold comments / questions until after others have had the chance to ask. Thank you for your support!

title: R-Ladies Freiburg: From messy data to beautiful plot: Guided TidyTuesday  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
Know the basics of data wrangling but want some hands-on practice? Want to learn ggplot tips and tricks to make your plots eye-catching? Seen cool visualizations on Twitter but find it hard to go from messy dataset to beautiful visualization?

In this monthly meetup, we‚Äôll go through a Tidy Tuesday dataset together step-by-step, walking you through the entire process from coming up with an interesting question to asnwer, getting the data in the right format and finally, creating a cool visualization!

You may have heard of Tidy Tuesday -- a weekly initiative by R for Data Science which provides a new dataset every week for the community to practice wrangling and visualizing. It has a huge Twitter community and is one of the best ways to practice and develop tidyverse skills, whether you‚Äôre still reviewing the basics or have quite the repertoire. This series has something for everyone and is especially designed to be beginner friendly!

It's important to us to ensure that Guided Tidy Tuesday is a safe space for gender minorities and especially those who are just starting out with R. Studies have shown that letting gender minorities speak first promotes a welcoming and supportive atmosphere for underrepresented groups. All are welcome at this meetup but we specifically ask cisgender men to take a passive role in this meetup and hold comments / questions until after others have had the chance to ask. Thank you for your support!

title: R-Ladies Washington D.C.: Books In Bars - The Code Breaker: Jennifer Doudna, gene editing, and the future   [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Spend Friday night discussing The Code Breaker (https://www.simonandschuster.com/books/The-Code-Breaker/Walter-Isaacson/9781982115852).

The bestselling author of Leonardo da Vinci and Steve Jobs returns with a gripping account of how Nobel Prize winner Jennifer Doudna and her colleagues launched a revolution that will allow us to cure diseases, fend off viruses, and have healthier babies.

When Jennifer Doudna was in sixth grade, she came home one day to find that her dad had left a paperback titled The Double Helix on her bed. She put it aside, thinking it was one of those detective tales she loved. When she read it on a rainy Saturday, she discovered she was right, in a way. As she sped through the pages, she became enthralled by the intense drama behind the competition to discover the code of life. Even though her high school counselor told her girls didn‚Äôt become scientists, she decided she would.

Driven by a passion to understand how nature works and to turn discoveries into inventions, she would help to make what the book‚Äôs author, James Watson, told her was the most important biological advance since his co-discovery of the structure of DNA. She and her collaborators turned ‚Äãa curiosity ‚Äãof nature into an invention that will transform the human race: an easy-to-use tool that can edit DNA. Known as CRISPR, it opened a brave new world of medical miracles and moral questions.

The development of CRISPR and the race to create vaccines for coronavirus will hasten our transition to the next great innovation revolution. The past half-century has been a digital age, based on the microchip, computer, and internet. Now we are entering a life-science revolution. Children who study digital coding will be joined by those who study genetic code.

Should we use our new evolution-hacking powers to make us less susceptible to viruses? What a wonderful boon that would be! And what about preventing depression? Hmmm‚Ä¶Should we allow parents, if they can afford it, to enhance the height or muscles or IQ of their kids?

After helping to discover CRISPR, Doudna became a leader in wrestling with these moral issues and, with her collaborator Emmanuelle Charpentier, won the Nobel Prize in 2020. Her story is a thrilling detective tale that involves the most profound wonders of nature, from the origins of life to the future of our species.

title: R-Ladies Dallas: "Journey through the tidyverse" with Dr. Che Smith  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
For the July 28 edition of our R-Ladies Dallas webinar series, we are excited to welcome Dr. Che Smith as our guest speaker. Dr. Smith will introduce the packages in the tidyverse!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Session title: Journey through the tidyverse
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Abstract: In a (recent) former life, I taught Data Science and Statistics at Davidson College with R and RStudio as my primary tools. Join me as I reflect on the wins and challenges of using RStudio to teach R applied to data science and statistics, framed in topics related to social justice, inequity, and community.

Bio: Che Smith is a data enthusiast whose career has spanned several industries and specialties. She is currently a Senior Analytics Engineer at Netflix, helping to continuously improve content performance metrics for titles launching on the streaming service. Prior to Netflix, Che taught data science and statistics at Davidson College and also directed a consulting and tutoring lab for the college. By training, Che is a biostatistician, and spent several years working with state and local health departments on using data in innovative ways. A long time R user, Che‚Äôs favorite super-package is tidyverse, and she loves to find datasets to wrangle, visualize, and draw insights from.

Twitter: @DrCheSmith

LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/chesmith1/
